newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine stocks pare gains at close, seen steady.
newsitem.headline: Argentine stocks pare gains at close, seen steady.

text.p: Most Argentine blue chip gains melted away on profit-taking at the close Wednesday despite an unrelenting surge in benchmark stock YPF, dealers said.

"The market hit technical targets which triggered sell programs, causing volume to swell dramatically and gains to fade away," said Jorge Bonanno at Interfin brokers. "Prices are now at reasonable levels and Thursday's performance will depend largely on U.S. economic indicators."
The blue-chip MerVal index .MERV slipped off a high of 671.6 to close at 664.58 with a 0.2 percent gain.
Floor volume soared to a hefty 37.5 million pesos from Tuesday's weak tally of 16.9 million, while over-the-counter turnover swelled to 202.3 million from Tuesday's 93.4 million.

"It was very busy here today and YPF was the star again after Tuesday's (2.4 percent) leap," said another trader. "The stock has now made up for lost territory compared to other blue chips and should stay more or less rangebound."

The oil giant's share shot up 3.9 percent to $26.75, its highest price since February 1994. Traders attributed the surge chiefly to a shift in international investment flows towards commodity stocks over the past two weeks.
"It's nothing special, just the right conditions for a key stock which was lagging the rest," Bonanno said.
The broad market rose 1.4 percent in the session, with 42 winners, half as many losers and 22 stocks closing flat.
Top main-tier performers included oil company Sol Petroleo and Telefonica, up 3.8 percent and 2.2 percent respectively.

The biggest losers were foods giant Molinos and construction stock Polledo, off 3.7 percent and 3.6 percent. Steelmaker Acindar shed 1.3 percent even though Santander initiated it Tuesday with a buy recommendation.
